comment.author: 22081583@N06
comment._content:
There were only about a dozen 4-funnelled warships in the Royal Navy about the time of this photograph. They were all armoured cruisers.
This ship looks as if it was HMS Euryalus, one of the Diadem Class of cruisers. Euryalus was based at Sydney on the Australian station between 1903 - 1905, so this is probably the period when this photo was taken.

comment.author: 22081583@N06
comment._content: The ship in the foreground appears to be one of the Cadmus Class of steel screw sloops. This is probably HMS Clio which was commissioned in January 1904 and sent out to the Australian station. She arrived in Sydney on 9 May 1904 and left on 18 June 1904. There was only a three week period in May and June 1904 when both the Clio and Euryalus were together in Sydney Harbour.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Great stuff, Picture Esk. According to this Wikipedia article HMS Euryalus was involved in the Gallipoli campaign, and was the headquarters there. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HMS_Euryalus_(1901)

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: Yes, thank you for that very useful information Picture Esk.

comment.author: 21726514@N02
comment._content: The position of masts and funnel on foreground ship looks out of proportion for HMS Clio - funnel is too far foward, as is midmast. Is this due to distance distortion ?

comment.author: 22081583@N06
comment._content: You could be right Rod. There is an image of HMS Clio's sister ship HMS Famtome available on Wikipaedia at en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:HMS_Fantome_%281901%29.jpg She is viewed at an angle from the stern, and the position of the funnel does not appear displaced. So we might be looking for another steel screw sloop?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There is some name on the stern (see note) using the Persistent URL link, zoom, full page and ++, and a magnifying glass.  Looks like T O S E ???

comment.author: 22081583@N06
comment._content:
I think that you have found the match there, well spotted.
And Torch was on the Australia Station in the early 1900s.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There were several times that 'Euryalus' and 'Torch' were in Sydney together in 1904-5, and there is a wonderful description in the SMH of 17/11/1905 p.7 of the Flagship HMS 'Euryalus' sailing for England, including what music the band played. "Torch had left an hour previously for Jervis Bay". trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14751242 Which might date this photo as the day before the sailing, ie Wednesday 15 November 1905.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Here's an April 1903 item from the T&CJ on HMS Euryalus, which had then been selected to replace HMS Royal Arthur as flagship of the Australian Station...per this article HMS Euryalus was expected in Sydney early in 1904 - nla.gov.au/nla.news-page5703417 ; here's a pictorial article which appeared in the T&CJ in April 1904, after HMS Euryalus arrived in Sydney - nla.gov.au/nla.news-article71508169 ; Here's a 1904 Sydney Mail item - news.google.com/newspapers?id=92xVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UpUDA...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: On this page there's a not too wonderful 1904 Sydney Mail pic of HMS Clio at Farm Cove...which I'll drop here for possible future reference - news.google.com/newspapers?id=_2xVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=UpUDA...
